notes.reading-notes:
SAMPLE READING NOTES
DEFINITION OF MOTIVATION: needs and wants that cause someone to take action
extrinsic motivation:
actions taken for reasons from outside
examples such as money, goods, attention, approval, praise
intrinsic motivation:
actions taken for oneself
examples such as satisfaction, pleasure, self-fulfillment, sense of accomplishment
overjustification effect:
action originally based on intrinsic motivation
extrinsic rewards offered for action
decrease in intrinsic motivation
notes.listening-notes:
SAMPLE LISTENING NOTES
TOPIC: Marnie, a singer
rewards in her life:
intrinsically motivated (singing for pleasure) as a teenager
extrinsically motivated later (singing due to others' expectations)
extrinsically motivated by professional contract (singing for money)
overjustification effect:
singing originally based on intrinsic motivation
extrinsic rewards (expectations and money) offered for singing
decrease in intrinsic motivation for singing
